  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Courses for Fall 2017</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> <div class="content">



		<div class="course-section" id="FREN">
			
				<ul class="course-list">
										<li id="FREN0100">
					<h4>Basic French</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This is the first half of a two-semester course. Four meetings a week for oral practice. One hour of work outside of class is expected every day (grammar/writing, oral practice, reading). Enrollment limited to 15. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15624">FREN 0100 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wiart</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15625">FREN 0100 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wiart</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15626">FREN 0100 S03</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wiart</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15628">FREN 0100 S05</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wiart</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN0300">
					<h4>Intermediate French I</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A semi-intensive elementary review with emphasis on all four skills (listening, speaking, reading and writing). Class activities include drills, small group activities, and skits. Class materials include videos, a French film, short stories, and various other authentic documents.  Prerequisite: FREN 0200 or placement (Previous experience with French is required to take this class). Four meetings per week, plus a 50-minute conversation section with TAs. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15725">FREN 0300 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wiart</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15726">FREN 0300 S03</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wiart</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN0400">
					<h4>Intermediate French II</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Continuation of FREN 0300 but may be taken separately. A four-skill language course that stresses oral interaction in class (three meetings per week plus one 50-minute conversation section). Materials include audio activities, film, and a novel. Short compositions with systematic grammar practice.  Prerequisite: FREN 0300, FREN 0200 with permission, or placement. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15634">FREN 0400 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wiart</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15635">FREN 0400 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wiart</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN0500">
					<h4>Writing and Speaking French I</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A four-skill language course that stresses oral interaction in class. Thematic units will focus on songs, poems, a short novel, a graphic novel, films and a longer novel. Activities include a creative project using Comic Life, and a systematic grammar review.  Prerequisite: FREN 0400, FREN 0200 with written permission, or placement. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15640">FREN 0500 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Izzo</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15641">FREN 0500 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Izzo</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15642">FREN 0500 S03</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Izzo</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15643">FREN 0500 S04</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Izzo</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN0600">
					<h4>Writing and Speaking French II</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Prerequisite for study in French-speaking countries. Class time is devoted mainly to conversation and discussion practice. Writing instruction and assignments focus on essays, commentaries, and to a lesser degree, on story writing. Apart from reading assignments for discussion (press articles and literary excerpts), students select two novels to read. Prerequisite: FREN 0500 or placement. Enrollment limited to 15. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15644">FREN 0600 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Ravillon</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																				<div class="additional-sections">
															
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15648">FREN 0600 S02</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Ravillon</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15649">FREN 0600 S03</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Ravillon</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15653">FREN 0600 S04</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Ravillon</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN0720D">
					<h4>Contes et identités francophones</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An introduction to the French-speaking world through folk- and fairy tales, we will examine how folktales have been used to define national and ethnic identities in France, Sénégal, the Caribbean, Louisiana, and Canada and consider how the study and rewriting of these traditions have redefined these identities. We will explore these questions by studying tale-types from all of the above regions, tales specific to each, and literary reworkings of folktales by writers, including d'Aulnoy, Perrault, Nothomb, Ben Jelloun, Diop, and Chamoiseau. Prerequisites: 5 on Advanced Placement testing, 700 and above SAT II, or instructor's permission.  Taught in French. FYS WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17306">FREN 0720D S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Seifert</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN1020A">
					<h4>Histoire de la langue française:  usages, politiques et enjeux du français</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">A study of the evolution of the French language from the Middle Ages to the present. We will trace the main periods of this linguistic, social, historical and political development. Among topics to be explored: France’s encounter with English from the Norman conquest to the current so-called English “invasion,” the French Revolution’s destruction of dialects (patois), and the status of French in France’s former colonial empire. Through a variety of French and francophone texts we will investigate the  transformations brought about by Feminists and by youth from the banlieues and examine the status of French outside of France.  In French. Prerequisite: a course at the 600- or 700-level or equivalent proficiency. Contact the instructor to verify your proficiency if you have not taken French at Brown. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15693">FREN 1020A S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Mostefai</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN1120F">
					<h4>L'enfer, c'est les autres</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">In this course we will read a selection of plays by notable 20th century French and Francophone writers, and consider how the dramatic form organizes and complicates questions of representation, subjectivity, body, politics and voice. Authors include Sartre, Camus, Genet, Beckett, Césaire, Koltès, Duras, Sarraute, Ndiaye, Redonnet. Secondary readings by Adorno, Deleuze, Kristeva amongst others. Taught in French. Prerequisite: a course at the 600- or 700-level or equivalent proficiency. Contact the instructor to verify your proficiency if you have not taken French at Brown. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17559">FREN 1120F S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Ravindranathan</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN1130G">
					<h4>Modernismes poétiques</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Poetry begins with (more) white space on the page. The modernist remaking of poetry - beginning somewhere in the second half of the 19th century and lasting more or less through the first half of the 20th – brought about an exponential increase in the volume of that space, and in various other extensions of it (e.g. into design and drawing, into the unconscious). The course will follow those transformations by reading poems and other writings by selected poets from Rimbaud and Mallarmé to the surrealists and Ponge. Taught in French. Prerequisite: a course at the 0600- or 0700-level or equivalent proficiency. Contact the instructor to verify your proficiency if you have not taken French at Brown. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16810">FREN 1130G S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wills</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN1150G">
					<h4>New Waves from Paris to Hollywood</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">“New wave” was coined by a journalist to refer to an “outburst” of filmmaking in France beginning in 1959. Never a movement, and short-lived in terms of whatever aesthetic uniformity it may have had, its effects spread across various European cinemas and became the emblem for a series of American filmmakers well into the 1970s. We will analyze work by a range of French and other cinéastes, in an attempt to understand what perhaps appears--from the current perspective--as one of the last gasps of “high cultural” production against the reality of corporate necessity and new forms of media. Taught in English. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15814">FREN 1150G S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wills</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN1310M">
					<h4>Le fantastique</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">Ghosts, spirits and specters populate the French "fantastique". Starting with the precursors of the genre in the 18th century (Jacques Cazotte’s Le Diable amoureux), we will read major works of "littérature fantastique" of the 19th century, including Balzac’s La Peau de chagrin (1831), Contes cruels by Villiers de l’Isle-Adam (1883) and Maupassant’s Le Horla (1886). Select readings from critical theory and philosophy will accompany the readings (Todorov, Bergson, Derrida). We will also consider examples of the fantastic in 20th century cinema (Epstein’s La Chute de la Maison Usher (1928) and Franju’s Les Yeux sans visage (1960). Taught in French. Prerequisite: a course at the 600- or 700-level or equivalent proficiency. Contact the instructor to verify your proficiency if you have not taken French at Brown. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=17516">FREN 1310M S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Odello</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN1410T">
					<h4>L'expérience des réfugiés/immigrés</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An exploration of the experience of refugees and immigrants with two components.  The first component consists of close study of the French context from Decolonization up through the current refugee crisis based on literature, film, the press, and critical essays.   The second component of this course will give students the opportunity to work with refugee/recent immigrant communities in Providence.  This is a community-engaged course requiring substantial commitment beyond the classroom.  Taught in French. Prerequisite: a course at the 0600- or 0700-level or equivalent proficiency. Contact the instructor to verify your proficiency if you have not taken French at Brown. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16812">FREN 1410T S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Krause</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN1510A">
					<h4>Advanced Oral and Written French: Traduction</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">An introduction to the theory and practice of translation, this course will be designed to expand students' range and appreciation of written styles and registers and will be based on translation exercises and texts reflecting different types of written and oral communication.Texts will range from literary texts (excerpts from novels, plays, comic books...) to journalistic texts (articles from newspapers...). Class activities will also include comparative studies of translated texts, as well as grammar review and vocabulary work. Course taught in French. Written translations to and from French. Prerequisite: FREN 0600 or equivalent. Enrollment limited to 18. Instructor permission required. WRIT </div>
		
					<div class="sections">

																							</dl>
						</div>

				</li>
										<li id="FREN2130H">
					<h4>Au-delà de l’Europe: La France et le monde au XVIIe siècle</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">In the 17th century, contact with the Middle East, India, the Far East, North and South America, and the Caribbean profoundly changed the ways the French understood themselves and their place in the world. We will study 17th-century depictions of the non-Western world in travel narratives, early ethnographic writing, drama, and fiction, including representations of religious difference, race, slavery, gender, and Orientalism. Readings: Bernier, Champlain, Choisy, Le Code noir, Galland, Marie de l’Incarnation, Les Mille et une nuits, Molière, Montaigne, Racine, the Relations des Jésuites de la Nouvelle-France, Scudéry, Tavernier. Theoretical readings by Anderson, Chakrabarty, Glissant, Said, i.a.  In French. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15800">FREN 2130H S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Seifert</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN2170M">
					<h4>L'Art de l'excès</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This seminar considers the late 19th-century idea of decadence, understood as extravagant reaction to perceived social dissipation and political decline. We will focus on the esthetics, politics, and practices of excess in fin-de-siècle fiction. Topics include: decadent estheticism, proto-fascism, altered states, and non-normative sexualities. Authors include Eekhoud, Lorrain, Huysmans, Péladan, Rachilde, Lemonnier, Vivien. Fictional texts will be accompanied by contemporary non-fictional sources (Nordau, Bourget, Kraft-Ebbing, Lombroso). Taught in French. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=16235">FREN 2170M S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Schultz</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN2600K">
					<h4>Politique et fiction en Afrique</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">This seminar investigates the political aesthetics of fiction in Francophone Africa with a special focus on our post-millennial period. We will examine new and established writers, filmmakers, and theorists as they rework conventions of postcolonial satirical and protest fiction and address contemporary problems of globalization, corruption, and social violence. How does current Francophone African fiction speak to contemporary political theory, and in what ways does this fiction address and constitute a politics of genre? And how does African fiction use politics to mediate its complicated relationship to theories of world literature?  Taught in French. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=15801">FREN 2600K S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Izzo</dd>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>

					<div class="course-overview">For graduate students who have completed their course work and are preparing for a preliminary examination. </div>

							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=13103">FREN 2980 S12</a></h5>
														<dl>
																<dt>Primary Instructor</dt><dd>Wiart</dd>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=13104">FREN 2980 S13</a></h5>
														<dl>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																		
												<div class="section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=13105">FREN 2980 S14</a></h5>
														<dl>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>I: Independent Study/Research</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
														
																										</div>
												</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FREN2990">
					<h4>Thesis Preparation</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">For graduate students who have met the tuition requirement and are paying the registration fee to continue active enrollment while preparing a thesis. </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5><a href="/academics/french-studies/COURSES/detail?term=201710&crn=14979">FREN 2990 S01</a></h5>
														<dl>
																								<dt>Schedule Code</dt><dd>E: Grad Enrollment Fee/Dist Prep</dd>
															</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
										<li id="FRENXLIST">
					<h4>Courses of Interest to French Concentrators</h4>
					<div class="course-overview">The following courses may be of interest to French concentrators.  Please see the sponsoring department for the time and location of each course.<br><br>
<b>Cogut Center for Humanities</b><br>
HMAN 2971D Caring for the Truth<br>
 </div>
		
					<div class="sections">
								
												
												<div class="section first-section">
												
							<h5>FREN XLIST 0</h5>
														<dl>
																							</dl>
						</div>
						
																					
																								</div>
						
				</li>
					</ul>
		
	</div> <!-- end .course-section -->



</div>



<script type="text/javascript">
	// @todo: make show/hide link dynamically generated
	$(document).ready(function(){
	
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").hide();

		// add additional sections toggle link
		$(".course-list .additional-sections").each(function(i,el){
			var numSections = $(".section", $(this)).length;
			numSections = (numSections == 1) ? numSections + " additional section" : numSections + " additional sections";
			var anchor = $(this).parents("li").attr('id');
			$(this).after('<span class="section-count">[<a href="#' + anchor + '">Show ' + numSections + '</a>]</span>');
		});

		// now add the show/hide event listeners		
		$(".section-count").each(function(i,el){
			$("a", this).bind("click keypress", function(){
				$(".additional-sections", $(this).parents("li")).slideToggle("fast");
				window.location.hash = $(this).attr("href");
				if($(this).html().match(/Show/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
				} else if($(this).html().match(/Hide/)) {
					$(this).html($(this).html().replace("Hide", "Show"));
				}
				this.text(($('#toggle').text() == 'Show more') ? 'Show less' : 'Show more');
				return false;
			});
		});
		
		if (window.location.hash) {
			var hash = window.location.hash;
			if(hash.match(/#[0-9]{4}/)) {
				$(hash +  " .additional-sections").slideDown("fast");
				$(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html($(hash +  " a[href='"+hash+"']").html().replace("Show", "Hide"));
			}
		}

	});
</script>
 </div>
                     </div>
        <!-- end .second-column -->

<header id="header-region">
<section id="audience-gateways">
  <div class="marginator">
    <h6>Information For:</h6>
    <ul>
      <li id="gateway-current-students" class="first"><a href="/gateway/current-students">Current Students</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-faculty"><a href="/gateway/faculty">Faculty</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-staff"><a href="/gateway/staff">Staff</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-families"><a href="/gateway/families">Families</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-alumni"><a href="/gateway/alumni">Alumni</a></li>
      <li id="gateway-friends-and-neighbors" class="last"><a href="/gateway/friends-and-neighbors">Friends &amp; Neighbors</a></li>
    </ul>
  </div>
</section>

        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Courses</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-818" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><strong>Graduate Courses</strong><br /><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/FALL%202017%20-%20SPRING%202018_1.pdf" target="_blank">Fall 2017 - Spring 2018</a><br /><br /><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/FALL%202016%20-%20SPRING%202017.pdf" target="_blank">Fall 2016 - Spring 2017</a>&nbsp;</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/FALL%202015%20-%20SPRING%202016.pdf" target="_blank">Fall 2015 - Spring 2016</a></p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/FALL%202014%20-%20SPRING%202015.pdf" target="_blank">Fall 2014 - Spring 2015</a></p>
  </div>

        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Undergraduate Courses</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-528" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2>Undergraduate Courses</h2>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/French%20UG%20Courses%20Spring2018_1.pdf" target="_blank">Spring 2018</a><span> </span><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/French%20UG%20Courses%20Fall2017_6.pdf">Fall 2017</a></p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/French%20UG%20Courses%20Spring2017.pdf" target="_blank">Spring 2017</a><span> <span> </span></span><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/French%20UG%20Courses%20Fall2016.pdf" target="_blank">Fall 2016</a><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/Spring%2016%20courses%20UG.pdf" target="_blank"><br /><br />Spring 2016</a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/Fall%2015%20courses%20UG_1.pdf" target="_blank">Fall 2015</a></p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/Spring%2015%20UG%20courses.pdf" target="_blank">Spring 2015</a> &nbsp; &nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/Fall%202014%20UG%20courses.pdf" target="_blank">Fall 2014</a></p>
  </div>

          <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/BrownUniversity" title="Facebook" id="footer-facebook">Facebook</a></li>

          <li><a href="http://www.youtube.com/brownuniversity" title="YouTube" id="footer-youtube">YouTube</a></li>
          <li><a href="http://itunes.apple.com/institution/brown-university/id381076688#ls=1" title="iTunes U" id="footer-itunesu">iTunes U</a></li>
          <li><a href="https://plus.google.com/100931085598361161047/posts" title="Google+" id="footer-google-plus">Google+</a></li>
          <li><a href="http://www.linkedin.com/company/brown-university" title="LinkedIn" id="footer-linkedin">LinkedIn</a></li>
          <li><a href="https://www.snapchat.com/add/brown-u" title="brown-u on Snapchat" id="footer-snapchat">SnapChat</a></li>
        </ul>
      </div>
    </div>

  <!-- Layout -->
  
  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-13" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h2><strong>The Doctoral Program in French Studies</strong></h2>
<p>Our graduate program offers a lively intellectual environment where students explore French and Francophone literatures and cultures across a broad chronological and topical range and through a wide variety of critical approaches.&nbsp; Our goal is to train scholars and teachers who have a solid grounding in all periods of French and Francophone literatures and who think, write, and teach creatively.&nbsp; Students work closely with&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/faculty-0">faculty</a>&nbsp;who provide individualized attention to each and every student. Students are paired with a faculty mentor who provides support and advice on an informal basis, assists students in preparing conference papers and articles for publication and gives careful guidance during the job search. Our program has a strong record of&nbsp;<a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/phd-alumni">job placement</a>&nbsp;for our <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/graduate/alumni-dissertations" target="_blank">recent graduates</a><span>. &nbsp;</span></p>
<p>Students in our program are guaranteed a competitive package of six years of academic year funding and four summers of financial support with full tuition remission and health and dental insurance coverage.&nbsp; Students are eligible for a dissertation fellowship during the fifth or sixth year.&nbsp; Additional summer funding is provided while they prepare for their preliminary exam, and a stipend for research travel is available during their dissertation fellowship year.&nbsp; In addition to six years of funding, students may choose to participate in a year-long teaching exchange with the Université de Bourgogne (Dijon) or the Université de Lyon 2-Louis Lumière.</p>
<p>A notable strength of our program is the in-depth training and experience students gain in language teaching, under the expert guidance of our Department’s language acquisition specialists.&nbsp; Students serve as Graduate Teaching Assistants in our language program during their second, third, and fourth years, teaching one section per semester.&nbsp;Our TAs are fortunate to work with some of the very best undergraduates in the country and to avail themselves of the certificate programs offered by the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/about/administration/sheridan-center/" target="_blank">Sheridan Center for Teaching and Learning</a>.&nbsp;</p>
<p>The Department hosts lectures, mini-seminars and conferences, including&nbsp;<span style="text-decoration:underline"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/conference/equinoxes/home" target="_blank">Equinoxes</a></span>, the annual graduate student conference.&nbsp; &nbsp;Shared with the Department of Hispanic Studies, <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/home/rochambeau-house-0" target="_blank">Rochambeau House</a>&nbsp;affords graduate students dedicated study space with computers, printers, and scanners. &nbsp;Funding from both the Graduate School and the Department is available for conference travel every year.&nbsp; The <a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/humanities/" target="_blank">Cogut Center for the Humanities</a>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/" target="_blank">Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women </a>offer fellowships for graduate students. The <a href="http://www.brown.edu/about/administration/global-engagement/news/2015-09/rfp-global-mobility-program-graduate-research-fellowship-grant" target="_blank">Office of Global Engagement´s Global Mobility Program </a>funds Graduate Research Fellowships for doctorate-level students to conduct research abroad for a summer or academic semester.</p>
<p>Graduate studies at Brown benefit from the accessibility of faculty across campus as well as the vitality of the humanities. Last but not least, Providence, Rhode Island is&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/courses-manual/financial-considerations" target="_blank">an affordable city</a>&nbsp;with&nbsp;<a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/gradschool/graduate/providence-ri" target="_blank">a vibrant cultural scene and an excellent quality of life</a>. &nbsp;It was recently named "the Country's Best Small City" by <a href="http://www.architecturaldigest.com/ad/travel/2014/providence-rhode-island-guide-hotels-restaurants-shops-article" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Architectural Digest</a> and "America's coolest city" by <a href="http://www.gq.com/story/providence-city-guide" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">GQ</a>.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p>For more information on the requirements and structure of the graduate program, and the application process, please consult the <span style="text-decoration:underline"><a href="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/uploads/2017-2018%20Graduate%20Handbook.pdf">Graduate Handbook</a></span> and <span style="text-decoration:underline"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/application" target="_blank">Application</a></span> pages.</p>
<p>Director of Graduate Studies, <a href="mailto:david_wills@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">David Wills</a>,&nbsp;Room 230, Rochambeau House.&nbsp;</p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
 </div>
                     </div>

	<div id="calendar" class="clear-block block block-calwidget ">

  <div id="content">
    <div class="marginator">
                  <div class="columns main-columns">
        <h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Current Graduate Students</h1>                        <div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">
                                                  <div class="clear-block"> 
<article id="node-389" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h5 style="padding-left:150px">Ph.D. Program in French Studies</h5>
<h5 style="padding-left:150px"><span>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Current Students</span></h5>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<table style="border-width:0px; border-style:solid; background-color:#ffffff" align="center">
<thead>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/Skype.thumbnail.PNG" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><strong><a href="mailto:sophie_brunau@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">SOPHIE BRUNAU-ZARAGOZA</a></strong></p>
<p><em>Licence</em> in English, Université François Rabelais, Tours, France, 2013.<br /><span><em>Master 1</em>&nbsp;in English, Université François Rabelais, Tours, France, 2016.<br /></span><span>M.A. in French, Michigan State University, 2016.</span></p>
<p><strong>Research interests:</strong>&nbsp; <span>21st century French society, political and social theory, radicalism, cultural studies, feminism and gender studies, ecocriticism and environmental activism.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/kclark_0.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><strong><a href="mailto:katherine_clark1@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">KATHERINE CLARK</a></strong></p>
<p>B.S. in <span>Applied Languages and Intercultural Studies</span>, Georgia Institute of Technology, 2016.</p>
<p><strong>Research interests:</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;<span>20th&nbsp;and 21st century literature, autobiography, psychoanalysis, film, and the cross-fertilization between literary and visual works of art.&nbsp;</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/Screen Shot 2017-06-20 at 12.59.21 PM.thumbnail.png" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><strong><a href="mailto:steven_davis3@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">STEVEN DAVIS</a></strong></p>
<p>B.A. in French, Hood College, 2013.<br /><span>M.A. in French Literature, Middlebury College, 2014.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><strong>Research interests:</strong><span>&nbsp; <span>16th century French literature and culture; Renaissance studies; early modern animal studies; intellectual history; animal-human relations; visual culture; ecocriticism; literary and cultural theory.</span></span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/Screen Shot 2016-08-01 at 10.24.36 AM.thumbnail.png" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><strong><a href="mailto:ryan_doherty@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">ATTICUS DOHERTY</a></strong></p>
<p>B.A. in French, Washington Lee University, 2014.<br /><span>B.S. in Biology, Washington Lee University, 2014.</span></p>
<p><strong>Research interests:</strong><span>&nbsp;&nbsp;<span>Late 19</span><sup>th</sup><span>&nbsp;century decadent literature, horror/terror in literature and theatre, psychoanalysis, gender and sexual identity in the 19</span><sup>th</sup><span>&nbsp;century, aesthetics.</span></span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/Ben16.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span><br /></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><a href="mailto:benjamin_fancy@brown.edu" rel="nofollow"><strong>BENJAMIN FANCY</strong></a></p>
<p align="left"><span>B.A. in English and French, University of Richmond, 2010.<br /></span><em>Master d’Etudes Anglophones</em><span>, Université de Toulouse - Jean Jaurès, France, 2013.<br /></span><span>M.A. in French Studies, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, 2014.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p><strong>Research interests:</strong>&nbsp;<span>17th-century French literature and culture; the early modern novel; fairy tales and folklore; gender and sexuality studies; literary rivalries; haunting and mourning in fiction; second language and writing pedagogy.<br /><br /><strong>Dissertation in progress:&nbsp;</strong><span>"Mourning, Imagination, and Absence in Seventeenth-Century French Fiction"</span></span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-center" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/jgibson.thumbnail.JPG" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><a href="mailto:Justin_Gibson@Brown.edu" rel="nofollow"><strong>JUSTIN GIBSON</strong></a><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>
<p align="left">B.A. in French, Eastern Kentucky University, 2005.<br /><span>M.A. in French, Middlebury College, 2008.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p align="left"><strong>Research interests:</strong>&nbsp;The guest/host relationship in Renaissance literature; representations of hospitality in classical epic and in various genres of early modern literature; regional identities in the early modern period, phenomenology, and ecocriticism.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/Screen Shot 2016-08-17 at 8.15.42 AM.thumbnail.png" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p><strong><a href="mailto:alan_gomez@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">ALAN GÓMEZ</a></strong></p>
<p>B.A. in French &amp; Francophone Studies, California State University, Long Beach, 2014.<br /><span>M.A. in French &amp; Francophone Studies, California State University, Long Beach, 2016.</span></p>
<p><strong>Research interests:</strong><span>&nbsp;</span><span>18th and 19th-century French literature and thought, Transatlantic Studies, Latin American Literature, Gender and Sexuality Studies, Maghrebi francophone literature, Translation/interpretation studies, Foreign Language Pedagogy, SLA.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/portrait 1.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span><br /></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><a href="mailto:Rebecca_Krasner@Brown.edu" rel="nofollow"><strong>REBECCA KRASNER</strong></a><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>
<p align="left">B.A. in French Language and Literature, Boston University, 2009.</p>
<p align="left"><strong>Research interests</strong><span>: 20th century and contemporary literature and cinema; translation; representations of the body; intersections between bodies and texts; notions of the text (and language) as corporeal object.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-center" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/mlarose.thumbnail.png" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><a href="mailto:marie_larose@brown.edu" rel="nofollow"><strong>MARIE LAROSE</strong></a></p>
<p align="left">B.A. in French, Rutgers University, 2009.<br /><span>M.A. in French, Rutgers University, 2013</span></p>
<p align="left"><strong>Research interests</strong><span>: the representation and manipulation of body and language in the works of Sade, Laclos and Sorel; the question of nostalgia in Caribbean novels; the representation of the Haitian Revolution in post-colonial narratives.&nbsp;</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/unnamed_4.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p><strong><a href="mailto:mark_leuning@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">MARK LEUNING</a></strong></p>
<p>Diplôme avancé d'études françaises, Université Rennes II, 2007<br />B.A. in French, Western Washington University, 2008<br /><span>B.Mus. in Vocal Performance, Western Washington University, 2008.<br />M.Mus. in Vocal Pedagogy and Performance, <br />The Boston Conservatory, 2014.<br /><strong><br />Research interests:&nbsp;</strong><span>Poetry of the 19th century, mélodie française, gender and sexuality studies, poetry and music, tragédie en musique, phonetics and lyric diction, second language acquisition, performance studies</span></span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/KM.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><strong><a href="mailto:kelly_mccray@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">KELLY MCCRAY</a></strong></p>
<div>B.A. in French and Women's &amp; Gender Studies, Smith College, 2006</div>
<div>M.A. in French Language &amp; Literature, University of Utah, 2015<br /><br /></div>
<p align="left"><strong>Research interests</strong><span>: <span>20th and 21st century French and francophone literature; feminism and gender studies; relationships between text and images; second language acquisition; foreign language pedagogy.&nbsp;</span></span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/IMG_1728.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p><strong><a href="mailto:kaitlyn_quaranta@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">KAITLYN QUARANTA</a></strong></p>
<p>B.A. in French, Boston College, 2014.<br /><span>M.A. in French, Boston College, 2016.</span></p>
<p><strong>Research interests:</strong><span>&nbsp; <span>18th century literature and philosophy, the social impact of literature, epistolary novels, fairy tales and cautionary tales of the early modern period, humor and irony, film</span></span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-center" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/crobinson.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><a href="mailto:Christopher_Robison@Brown.edu" rel="nofollow"><strong>CHRISTOPHER ROBISON</strong></a><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>
<p align="left">B.A. in Comparative Literature and French, University of Rochester, 2009.</p>
<p align="left"><strong>Research interests: </strong>the philosophy and fiction of the 17th and 18th centuries; early modern theories of language; Franco-Russian literary interactions from the Enlightenment onwards.&nbsp;</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-center" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/stepanov.thumbnail.JPG" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p align="left"><a href="mailto:brigitte_stepanov@brown.edu" rel="nofollow"><strong>BRIGITTE STEPANOV</strong></a><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>
<p align="left">B.A.H. in French Studies and Mathematics, Queen's University at Kingston, Canada, 2013.</p>
<p align="left"><strong>Research interests: </strong><span>20th-century and contemporary French and Francophone literature and cinema; war, trauma, the limits of representation; comparative literature (Russian/English/French); Medieval literature; links between literature and mathematics, literature and technology.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background-color:#ffffff">
<td><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/academics/french-studies/sites/brown.edu.academics.french-studies/files/images/4dd784cd-3bf3-4620-83e2-eab4485c9c53.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></td>
<td>
<p><strong><a href="mailto:mary_williams@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">LAURIN WILLIAMS</a></strong></p>
<p>B.A. in French, Boston University, 2014.</p>
<p><strong>Research interests:</strong><span>&nbsp;&nbsp;<span>Twentieth century and contemporary French and Francophone literature; Algerian literature; the representation of violence, terror, and memory; gender and identity; intertextuality in literature and film.</span></span></p>
</td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<div class="image-clear"></div>  </div>
